reviewText: Interesting if fairly average Euro-crime flick. The WB DVD R sports a nice transfer. See show biz worlds collide as an aged and out-of-it Rita Hayworth hams it up with a typically villainous and heart-attack obsessed Klaus Kinski. Margaret Lee and Claudine Auger are on hand for some eye candy. Cool late-60s American Southwest locations give the film added appeal. Bizarre ending seems like the filmmakers just ran out of time and walked away. Probably not for everyone but fans of Italian-style crime capers will appreciate it.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I just noticed that Amazon made a serious mistake, as the picture is supposed to be CATS the musical, somehow it has reviews from a totally differnet movie "The Cats" (1968).And there is another item for "Cats: Ultimate Edition [Blu-ray]", but the reviews were mixed with the older DVD movie, what a mess!Anyhow let's do a quick comparison:DVD, Ancient navigation menu.Audio track: Up to Dolby 5.1Extra: The Making of Cats.Subtitle: For some reason, I can't get my bluray players (as well as Xbox One) to show any subtitle. It does work with VLC software player, though sometimes it has horrible lip sync issue.Bluray: Better video, granted it's not up to current Bluray standard (Could be that it's recorded with none HD camera), but still a noticeable improvement. On DVD there are horizontal black bars on top and bottom of screen. On Bluray there is none!Audio: On top of Dolby 5.1, it now has DTS 5.1.Extra: It has two more, "Interview with the original creative team", which has quite some very insightful information. "Character Makeup Featurette", a little comparison of before and after makeup.Subtitle: Oh my gosh, it now has 29 languages! I honestly think that's too much. It's kinda fun to see how they translate the lyrics into different languages though, some of them are silly.If you're a fan of Cats, I'd wholeheartedly recommend this fantastic bluray.
summary: Excellent! A significant improvement over DVD.

reviewText: I bought this DVD because Rita Hayworth was in it. That's all. The movie was fair. An English dubbed Italion film with very bad sync. Only a Rita Hayworth collector need by this film. It has no other merit. The seller has nothing to do with the film. It came in perfect condition. It is a shame Rita made this film towards the end of her movie career. She does not act or look good in it. It is a shame that many of the great Hollywood beauties continued to make bad films after their youth went be bye bye, Ava Gardner, Lana Turner including Rita made bad choices. They were still good, but the cheap films they made were terrible. What more can I say!  Bob Anderson

reviewText: Director Duccio Tessari and actor Giuliano Gemma made many genres films together and this one is one of their best, 'THE CATS' aka 'I BASTARDI'- 1968 released by Warner Archive.  The film resembles a Ma Parker gangster film involving actress Rita Hayworth in one of her last roles playing an alcoholic  mother ruling her sons Gemma and cult actor Klaus Kinski in an evil performance with an iron fist.  Revenge is the game however after a jewel heist is ambushed by Kinski and in a case of sibling rivalry, he absconds with Gemma's girlfriend played by beautiful Margaret Lee as Gemma winds up getting the muscle tendons in his hands sliced and diced.  Nursed back together by equally gorgeous Claudine Auger , he orchestrates vengeance with a passion till a frustratingly abrupt ending prevents this film from getting five stars. Tessari directs the script co-written by himself and Ennio Di Concini like a Spaghetti Western at a rapid pace never having the humor which would discolor his later efforts interfering with the proceedings. Euro fans will also spot Dan Van Husen and Umberto Raho along for the ride. With a great lounge score by Michel Magne resembling Herb Alpert and his Tijuana Brass in some spots and beautiful cinematography by Carlo Carlini, its a must for fans of Italian cinema and also the chance in seeing two beautiful actresses ,Auger and Lee, strutting their stuff.  Unfortunately, Rita Hayworth chews the scenery so hard you expect cardboard to spit out of her mouth alongside the saliva. Joan Crawford was supposed to play the role but turned it down. Too bad, at the time she was doing some over the top roles herself and might have given this film a slightly needed cutting edge . Warner releases it in an English dubbed  1.85 DVD-R transfer with its original Italian beginning and end titles but, sadly, no extras.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This underrated movie of 1968 is suprisingly entertaining. The versions that one had seen before had a bad picture quality. This one has been remastered to perfection. You see Italian western star Guiliano Gemma, German cult star Klaus Kinski and French model and actress Claudine Auger in a typical international spaghetti western type movie, directed by Duccio Tesarri, who was the perfect choice for this kind of flicks. The story is about two gangster-brothers that hate each other - "the Cats"( or "the Bastards") ... and their strange relationship to their mother who loves both her sons. She is played by the former screen legend Rita Hayworth in one of her last roles. Hayworth's part is especially touching when we see her with a glass of whiskey in her hand, looking at old pictures of her glamourous past.
Title: N/A
